designIssues.name: God Class
designIssues.description: The InputProcessor class has 11 methods performing multiple unrelated responsibilities

designIssues.name: Single Responsibility Principle (SRP) Violation
designIssues.description: The class is responsible for managing input processing, status tracking, and various utility functions, violating SRP

designIssues.name: Feature Envy
designIssues.description: Methods primarily use global variables rather than their own class variables, indicating tight coupling with external state

designIssues.name: High Complexity
designIssues.description: Multiple unrelated responsibilities distributed across many methods with high cohesion complexity

explanation: To address these design issues, extract one or more classes from InputProcessor (such as InputManager, StatusTracker, InputUtility). This refactoring will distribute responsibilities appropriately, improving modularity and reducing coupling.

keyBenefits.title: Potential Improvement in Design Quality
keyBenefits.description: Extracting multiple classes from InputProcessor will significantly improve the modularity of the class, reducing its coupling and aligning it better with the SRP. This will have a high positive impact on the overall design quality of the codebase.

keyBenefits.title: Estimated Effort and Complexity
keyBenefits.description: The proposed 'extract class' refactoring is relatively straightforward and should not introduce a high level of complexity or effort compared to other potential refactorings.

keyBenefits.title: Reduced Risk of Regressions
keyBenefits.description: The refactoring is focused on improving the modularity of the class and does not involve major structural changes to the codebase. This reduces the risk of introducing new issues or regressions during the refactoring process.

keyBenefits.title: Overall Impact on Maintainability and Extensibility
keyBenefits.description: By improving the modularity and reducing the coupling, the refactoring will have a positive impact on the long-term maintainability and extensibility of the codebase. This is a key consideration in the ranking process.

proposedClasses.name: StatusTracker
proposedClasses.responsibility: Tracking the last processed input and total process count

proposedClasses.name: InputUtility
proposedClasses.responsibility: Providing utility functions related to input processing

designIssues.name: Feature Envy
designIssues.description: The method exhibits high fan-in usage, being more interested in operations from other classes than its own responsibilities

designIssues.name: Tight Coupling with Global State
designIssues.description: Heavy reliance on external dependencies rather than internal state

designIssues.name: Limited Reusability
designIssues.description: The method is tightly coupled, making it difficult to reuse processing logic in different contexts

designIssues.name: Responsibility Concentration
designIssues.description: Contains specific processing logic that could be better encapsulated in separate, focused methods

explanation: To resolve these design issues, extract the processing logic into separate, focused methods (e.g., validateInput(), transformInput(), executeProcessing()). This breaks down the monolithic method into smaller, single-purpose methods that can be reused independently.

keyBenefits.title: Improved Code Reusability
keyBenefits.description: Separating input processing logic into dedicated methods allows these methods to be reused in different contexts without being tied to the processInput method.

keyBenefits.title: Reduced Complexity
keyBenefits.description: Extracting specific concerns from processInput reduces the method's cyclomatic complexity and makes it easier to understand and maintain.

keyBenefits.title: Better Encapsulation
keyBenefits.description: Each extracted method can encapsulate a single concern, improving the clarity of the code and making dependencies explicit.

keyBenefits.title: Enhanced Testability
keyBenefits.description: Smaller, focused methods are easier to unit test in isolation, enabling better test coverage and reducing test complexity.

proposedMethods.name: transformInput
proposedMethods.responsibility: Transform and prepare input for processing

proposedMethods.name: Multiple Responsibilities
proposedMethods.description: Combines two distinct concerns - processing inputs and resetting the processor state

proposedMethods.name: Feature Envy with High Fan-out
proposedMethods.description: The method has many dependencies on other classes, indicating excessive coupling

proposedMethods.name: Single Responsibility Principle (SRP) Violation
proposedMethods.description: Two separate concerns should not be handled by a single method

proposedMethods.name: Lack of Flexibility
proposedMethods.description: Users cannot perform processing without resetting, or reset without processing, limiting utility

explanation: The processAndReset method combines the responsibilities of processing inputs and resetting the processor. High fan-out indicates this method has many dependencies. By separating these concerns into distinct methods, each method can have a single, clear responsibility, improving cohesion and reducing coupling.

keyBenefits.title: Single Responsibility Adherence
keyBenefits.description: Splitting processAndReset into separate methods ensures each method has one clear purpose, adhering to the Single Responsibility Principle.

keyBenefits.title: Reduced Fan-Out
keyBenefits.description: Separating concerns reduces the number of dependencies each method has, making the code less tightly coupled and more flexible.

keyBenefits.title: Independent Method Invocation
keyBenefits.description: Methods can now be called independently, allowing developers to process data without necessarily resetting, or vice versa, providing more flexibility.

keyBenefits.title: Improved Code Clarity
keyBenefits.description: Clear method names that reflect single responsibilities make the code more readable and easier to understand at a glance.

proposedMethods.name: Multiple Responsibilities
proposedMethods.description: Combines two distinct concerns - adding/storing input and processing it

proposedMethods.name: Feature Envy
proposedMethods.description: Method shows signs of being more interested in external operations than maintaining its own state

proposedMethods.name: Single Responsibility Principle (SRP) Violation
proposedMethods.description: Two separate operations should not be combined in a single method

proposedMethods.name: Limited Method Composability
proposedMethods.description: Cannot independently add without processing or process previously added inputs

explanation: The addAndProcess method combines the responsibilities of adding an input and processing it. These are two distinct concerns that should be separated into independent methods. This refactoring improves code clarity, reusability, and makes the code more flexible for different use cases.

keyBenefits.title: Improved Code Clarity
keyBenefits.description: Separating addition and processing into distinct methods makes the intent clearer and reduces cognitive load when reading the code.

keyBenefits.title: Enhanced Reusability
keyBenefits.description: Independent methods can be reused in different combinations, allowing developers to add without processing, or process previously added inputs.

keyBenefits.title: Better Testability
keyBenefits.description: Each method can be tested independently, making test cases simpler and reducing the number of edge cases to handle.

keyBenefits.title: Flexible Method Composition
keyBenefits.description: Methods can be composed in different ways to handle various scenarios, providing more flexibility in how the class is used.
